<<<code>>>: public class ByteDecoder {
public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
InputStream is = new FileInputStream("byte.log");
DataInputStream dis = new DataInputStream(is);
int count = is.available();
byte[] bs = new byte[count];
dis.read(bs);
for (byte b : bs) {
char c = (char) b;
if (c == '(' || c == ')') {
// Convert bytes to hex string
String hexString = DatatypeConverter.printHexBinary(bs);
System.out.println(hexString.substring(0, c.length()));
} else {
System.out.println(c);
}
}
}
}

Explanation:
You can use the DataInputStream to read the binary data and then check for the characters '(' and ')' to determine the start and end of the substring. Once you have determined the start and end of the substring, you can use the DatatypeConverter.printHexBinary method to convert the bytes to a hex string. Finally, you can use the substring method to extract the portion of the hex string that corresponds to the characters '(' and ')' and print it out.
